title: The car stereo installer turned millionaire cannabis grower
text:
Michael Bailey Rich List Editor Oct 22, 2019 — 12.00am Share

Joshua Fegan’s journey from installing car stereos to founding and running one of Australia’s largest medical cannabis suppliers might seem an incongruous one.

But for the 35-year-old, who has debuted in the 57th spot on the 2019 Financial Review Young Rich List with wealth of $56 million thanks to his 28 per cent shareholding in hot ASX-listed “pot stock” Althea Group, it’s all connected.

The La Trobe University business graduate had by 2009 worked his way up to national sales manager at Strathfield Group, they of “drive in and jive away” fame, when he realised he had to break away from the struggling consumer electronics retailer.

Fegan convinced his managers to let him start a separate franchised business of mobile installers who would travel around to car dealerships putting in radios, global positioning systems and reversing cameras.

“I’d noticed that the healthiest part of Strathfield was always the installation. The margins there were much better than any product on the shelf,” he says.

The entrepreneur took the franchise nationwide, selling it off after the wider Strathfield Group collapsed into administration in 2015, and used the proceeds to start Althea.

Doctors know absolutely nothing about it – they weren’t taught marijuana in medical school. — Joshua Fegan

Why medical cannabis? A step-uncle who lived in Seattle had been instrumental in its legalisation in Washington state in 1998. He had since moved into recreational cannabis – legalised in 2012 – and told Fegan business was going rather well. “I was like, mate, is that even legit?”

Fegan followed the campaign to legalise medical cannabis in Australia, where laws to that effect were passed in February 2016.
description: 'I was like, mate, is that even legit?' How this Young Rich Lister found his way into the medical cannabis business.
